abstract.text: A mechanism for generating requests to authenticate users based on their Apple ID.

abstract.text: Make it easy for users to log into apps and services.
The encapsulation of a successful authorization by a controller.
A control you add to your interface that enables users to initiate the Sign In with Apple flow.
A credential that results from a successful Apple ID authentication.
An identifier for the authenticated user.
A mechanism for generating requests to authenticate users based on their Apple ID.
Possible values for the credential state of a user.
Creates a new Apple ID authorization request.
A notification that indicates the user’s credentials have been revoked and they should be signed out.
Returns the credential state for the given user in a completion handler.
An OpenID authorization request that relies on the user’s Apple ID.
A controller that manages authorization requests that a provider creates.
An OpenID authorization request.
An interface that authorization providers must implement.
The view that creates the Sign in with Apple button for display.
Provide a way for users of your app to set up an account and start using your services.

doc://com.apple.authenticationservices/d.title: Implementing User Authentication with Sign in with Apple

abstract.text: Build a fluid sign-in experience for your tvOS apps using AuthenticationServices.

doc://com.apple.authenticationservices/d.title: Simplifying User Authentication in a tvOS App

abstract.text: An entitlement that lets your app use Sign in with Apple.
A button that you can use to trigger a Sign in with Apple request.
The root class of most Objective-C class hierarchies, from which subclasses inherit a basic interface to the runtime system and the ability to behave as Objective-C objects.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
A thread-safe type whose values can be shared across arbitrary concurrent contexts without introducing a risk of data races.
